arguments.desc: Defines the document as HTML5.

arguments.name: <html>
arguments.desc: Wraps the entire content of the HTML document.

arguments.name: <head>
arguments.desc: Contains information like <title> and meta tags.

arguments.name: <body>
arguments.desc: Holds all visible content such as headings and paragraphs.

arguments.name: ,
arguments.desc: Display a main heading and a short paragraph.

solutionBlock.overview: This warm-up checks that you can lay out the minimal, standards-compliant HTML document. A strong answer includes the doctype, a language attribute on `<html>`, a `<head>` with charset and title, and a `<body>` containing visible content. It’s about correctness, not styling.

approaches.title: Approach 1 – Basic HTML Skeleton
approaches.prose: Start with `<!DOCTYPE html>` to declare HTML5. Add `<html lang="en">` as the root element. Inside `<head>`, include `<meta charset="UTF-8">` and a descriptive `<title>`. Then place content in `<body>`, such as an `<h1>` and a short paragraph, to show the structure is valid and complete.

pitfalls: Forgetting the <!DOCTYPE html> declaration can cause browsers to enter quirks mode.
The <title> element must be inside <head>, not <body>.
techniques: Always define language using <html lang='en'>.
Indent nested elements for readability.

title: Inline vs Block Elements

description.summary: Demonstrate the difference between block and inline elements using pure HTML. Show that block elements start new lines while inline elements flow within text without breaking layout, and explain the difference in a short summary section.

arguments.name: <main>
arguments.desc: Wrap the core content in a main landmark to keep the structure clean and accessible.
Paragraphs are block-level elements; each paragraph starts on a new line.

arguments.name: <strong>
arguments.desc: Strong emphasis is inline; it flows within the same line of text.
Images are inline by default; they sit in the text flow (make sure it has a non-empty alt).

solutionBlock.overview: This task demonstrates default display roles using HTML only. Block elements like paragraphs start on new lines and take full width, while inline elements like strong and img flow within a line. The markup should make the difference obvious without any CSS edits or extra wrappers.

title: Links and Images

description.summary: Create semantic links and images: use anchor elements with descriptive text, add target/rel when opening new tabs, and include alt text for images. This checks basic accessibility, security, and HTML best practices in one exercise, including proper link labeling.

arguments.name: <a>
arguments.desc: Wraps content to make it clickable and navigates to another page or resource.

arguments.name: href
arguments.desc: Specifies the URL to navigate to when the link is clicked.

arguments.name: target="_blank"
arguments.desc: Opens the link in a new browser tab or window (may be blocked in sandboxed previews).

arguments.name: rel="noopener noreferrer"
arguments.desc: Prevents tab-napping and avoids giving the opened tab access to window.opener.
Displays an image; must include a non-empty alt attribute for accessibility.

returns.desc: A clickable image link with target='_blank', rel='noopener noreferrer', and a non-empty alt.

examples:
My Favorite Website

Click the image below to visit Wikipedia:

If this preview is sandboxed, the new tab may be blocked — that's expected.

web.starterHtml:
Clickable Image Practice

Your goal: make the image below link to another site.

Note: This embedded preview may block opening new tabs. Your code is still correct if the attributes are present.

solutionBlock.overview: Links and images are foundational for accessibility and SEO. Links should be descriptive and unique so screen readers can announce them meaningfully, and images should always include alt text that reflects purpose. If a link opens a new tab, rel=noopener noreferrer is required for security and performance best practices.

approaches.title: Approach 1 – Secure clickable image link
approaches.prose: Add an anchor with clear, descriptive text and a valid href (avoid generic 'click here'). If target blank is required, include rel noopener noreferrer. Add an img with a valid src and descriptive alt that explains the image’s content or purpose. Keep markup simple and semantic so tests and accessibility checks pass, and ensure links remain understandable out of context.

If this preview is sandboxed, opening a new tab may be blocked. The markup is still correct.

pitfalls: Forgetting rel='noopener noreferrer' is a security risk when using target='_blank'.
Leaving alt empty makes the image inaccessible.
In sandboxed iframes, clicks may not open a new tab even when the markup is correct.
techniques: Wrap directly inside for a clickable image.
Always combine target='_blank' with rel='noopener noreferrer' for external links.
Validate structure and attributes instead of relying on real navigation in embedded previews.

title: Lists and Navigation

description.summary: Build a semantic navigation bar using `nav > ul > li > a` with hash links. Use CSS `:target` to show only one section at a time without JavaScript, and ensure the Home section is visible by default when no hash is present.

arguments.name: <nav>
arguments.desc: Defines the primary navigation region (add an accessible label).

arguments.name: <ul>, <li>
arguments.desc: Use a list to group the navigation links.

arguments.name: <a href="#...">
arguments.desc: Each link must point to a section id on the same page (hash link).

arguments.name: <section id="...">
arguments.desc: Create three sections with ids: home, about, contact. Home must be last.

arguments.name: CSS :target
arguments.desc: Use :target to show the currently selected section based on the URL fragment.

returns.desc: A semantic navigation bar and three sections where only one section is visible at a time using CSS :target (no JavaScript).

examples: Expected structure: nav > ul > li > a with href values #home, #about, #contact; sections with matching ids (home last).

web.starterHtml:
• Home
  • About
  • Contact

About

Write something about this page.

Contact

Add contact details or a short message.

Home

Home should be visible by default when there is no hash.

solutionBlock.overview: Use an unordered list for the nav links and anchor each link to a section id. The CSS `:target` selector controls visibility: the targeted section is shown while others are hidden. Ordering matters so the default Home section remains visible when no hash exists, and becomes hidden when another section is targeted.

approaches.title: Approach 1 – CSS-only navigation with :target
approaches.prose: Create `<nav aria-label="Primary">` with a `<ul>` of links to `#home`, `#about`, `#contact`, etc. Give each `<section>` the matching id. Keep the Home section last in the DOM so a general sibling selector can hide it when another section is targeted. With no hash, Home stays visible by default.
approaches.codeHtml:
• Home
  • About
  • Contact

About

This section becomes visible when the URL hash is #about.

Contact

This section becomes visible when the URL hash is #contact.

Home

Home is visible by default (when there is no hash).

pitfalls: Forgetting to match each link href to a real section id.
Not keeping #home last (the sibling selector relies on document order).
Trying to toggle the HTML hidden attribute with CSS (it won't work as intended here).
techniques: Use <nav> + list markup for semantic navigation.
Use :target to react to URL fragments without JavaScript.

title: Semantic Page Layout

description.summary: Build a semantic page layout using header, nav, main, section, article, and footer. Focus on correct landmarks, heading hierarchy, and structure rather than styling or layout hacks so the document outline remains clear and accessible.

arguments.name: <header>
arguments.desc: Introductory content for the page (usually includes the main heading).

arguments.name: <main>

arguments.name: <article>
arguments.desc: A self-contained post. You must create exactly two articles.

arguments.name: <section>
arguments.desc: Groups the main content inside each article (put the post body here).

arguments.name: <footer>

solutionBlock.overview: A semantic layout uses header, nav, main, section, article, and footer to describe the page structure to assistive tech and search engines. The goal is to place content in the correct landmarks with a clear heading hierarchy so the page is navigable even without CSS and the document outline is meaningful and consistent.

approaches.title: Approach 1 — Replace wrappers with semantic layout

Avoid extra div wrappers unless needed, and keep heading levels consistent to reflect the document outline and meet the tests. Ensure there is exactly one main element and that semantic elements are used for structure, not presentation.

techniques: Use one clear page hierarchy: header → main → article/section → footer.
Put the page’s primary heading (<h1>) inside <header>.

title: Tables and Accessibility

description.summary: The goal is to provide a semantic table that screen readers can navigate, with a clear caption and correct header associations. Add headers with scope, captions, and keyboard considerations; test with screen readers and complex tables.

arguments.name: <table>
arguments.desc: Defines a table for displaying tabular data.

arguments.name: <caption>
arguments.desc: Provides a concise description of the table’s contents for accessibility.

arguments.name: <thead> and <tbody>
arguments.desc: Separate the header row from the main table body.

arguments.name: <th>
arguments.desc: Defines column headers, typically placed inside <thead>.

arguments.name: scope="col"
arguments.desc: Specifies that a header cell applies to an entire column, improving screen reader navigation.

returns.desc: An accessible employee table with caption, headers, and rows, structured using semantic HTML.

examples:
Employee Directory
Name Role Email
Alice JohnsonDesigneralice@example.com
Bob SmithDeveloperbob@example.com
Carol LeeManagercarol@example.com

web.starterHtml:
Employee Directory

Below, build a semantic table with three employees and columns for name, role, and email.

solutionBlock.overview: Assistive tech relies on th scope to announce headers correctly. Without proper thead/tbody structure and caption, users lose context when navigating cell by cell.

approaches.title: Approach 1 – Accessible Employee Table
approaches.prose: Include a caption describing the dataset, use thead for column headers, and tbody for data rows. If rows have headers, mark them with th scope='row'. Avoid layout tables and keep the markup purely semantic.
approaches.codeHtml:
Employee Directory
Name Role Email
Alice JohnsonDesigneralice@example.com
Bob SmithDeveloperbob@example.com
Carol LeeManagercarol@example.com

pitfalls: Forgetting to add a <caption> makes the table less accessible to screen readers.
Leaving out scope attributes can confuse assistive technologies.
Avoid using tables for layout purposes — use them only for structured data.
techniques: Use <thead> and <tbody> to separate structure from content.
Always include <caption> for a clear summary.
Use scope='col' for column headers and scope='row' for row headers if present.

title: Contact Form with Proper Labels

description.summary: The success message should only appear after a valid submit, so native validation must be enabled and the form action should target the success section. Consider edge cases like invalid email and required fields; test accessibility by associating labels and using native validation.

arguments.name: <form action="#thanks">
arguments.desc: Navigates to #thanks only when the submission is not blocked by HTML constraint validation.

arguments.name: Constraint validation
arguments.desc: Use required + type="email" (optionally minlength) so invalid submissions are blocked and #thanks is not reached.

arguments.name: :target
arguments.desc: Shows the success message only when the URL fragment is #thanks.

returns.desc: An accessible contact form with labeled, required fields. Submitting a valid form reveals a success message without JavaScript.

examples: Try submitting empty fields → browser blocks submit; success message stays hidden.

web.starterHtml:
Contact support

Message sent

Thanks! We received your message and will reply soon.

solutionBlock.overview: Native HTML validation is enough here: required fields and input types block invalid submissions, and the CSS :target pattern reveals the success state. This keeps the solution accessible and JS-free.

approaches.title: Approach 1 – Valid submit reveals success via :target
approaches.prose: Ensure each input has a label and a unique id, add required to mandatory fields, and use type=email for the email field. Keep the form action pointing to #thanks so the success message becomes visible only after validation passes.
approaches.codeHtml:
Contact support

pitfalls: Using novalidate disables browser validation, so invalid submits would still reach #thanks.
This pattern signals 'valid submit attempt', not server-confirmed delivery.
Using method="get" means form values may appear in the URL query string.
techniques: Rely on required + type="email" so invalid submits are blocked.
Use action="#thanks" + :target for a no-JS success message.
Optionally add minlength on the message to reduce accidental empty-ish submits.

title: Forms: Validation and Required Fields

description.summary: Build a signup form using native HTML5 validation: required fields, type constraints, minlength, and pattern. The browser should block invalid submissions without custom JS changes, and existing JS/CSS should remain untouched for tests.

arguments.name: required
arguments.desc: Ensures the user must fill out this field before the form can be valid.

arguments.name: type
arguments.desc: Determines the input’s format, such as 'email' for built-in email validation.

arguments.name: minlength
arguments.desc: Specifies the minimum number of characters required for a text input.

arguments.name: pattern
arguments.desc: Defines a regular expression the input value must match (for example, a password policy).

arguments.name: constraint validation API
arguments.desc: The browser exposes form.checkValidity(), input.checkValidity(), and form.reportValidity() based on these attributes.

returns.desc: A signup form with Name, Email, and Password fields that uses HTML attributes to enforce validity and shows a small status message after a submit attempt.

examples: Password policy example: at least 8 characters, including 1 uppercase letter and 1 number.

web.starterHtml:
Signup Form

Add inputs for Name, Email, and Password. Use HTML5 validation attributes (required, type, minlength, pattern) so the form is invalid until inputs are correct. Do not add novalidate. You don’t need to send data anywhere; focus on validation behavior.

solutionBlock.overview: Native HTML validation should enforce required fields and correct formats before submission. Using type=email, minlength, and pattern rules lets the browser handle most validation without custom JS. The existing JS and CSS rely on these attributes, so changing markup is the key step and should be kept minimal and precise.

approaches.title: Approach 1 – Attribute-driven validation
approaches.prose: Wire labels to inputs with for/id, add required to all fields, set type=email on the email input, and apply minlength and pattern to the password. Keep the provided JS and CSS unchanged so the built-in validation UI is used and tests pass reliably. Ensure each input has a label for accessibility.
approaches.codeHtml: Signup Form

pitfalls: Missing for/id pairing makes labels less accessible and breaks click-to-focus behavior.
A pattern that is too strict can block valid user input; test it with real examples.
Using novalidate disables browser validation APIs like reportValidity().
techniques: Use type="email" for built-in email validation.
Use minlength + pattern for password policies.
Add autocomplete tokens (name/email/new-password) for faster form filling.

webSolutionHtml: Signup Form

title: SEO: Essential <head> Metadata

description.summary: You’re given a simple marketing page that renders fine in the browser, but it’s missing production-grade <head> metadata. Update ONLY the <head> so the page has correct encoding, mobile-friendly viewport behavior, a descriptive title, and a meta description. Do not change the <body>. No CSS/JS changes are needed.

arguments.name: <meta charset="utf-8">
arguments.desc: Defines UTF-8 encoding so text renders consistently (including Turkish characters).

arguments.name: <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">
arguments.desc: Makes the page layout match device width on mobile (prevents weird zoom / scaling).

arguments.name: <title>Brand – Page intent</title>
arguments.desc: Sets the browser tab title and is a primary on-page SEO signal; should be specific, not just “Home”.

arguments.name: <meta name="description" content="...">
arguments.desc: Short summary of the page (commonly used for search snippets); keep it readable and concrete.

arguments.name: <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">
arguments.desc: Loads the provided CSS from the CSS file (avoid <style> tags in this challenge).

returns.desc: A valid HTML document where the <head> contains charset, viewport, a non-empty title, and a non-empty meta description (and keeps CSS in the external stylesheet).

examples:
<head>
  <meta charset="utf-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">
  <title>FrontendAtlas – Frontend Interview Practice</title>
  <meta name="description" content="Practice real interview-style frontend tasks with clear solutions and explanations.">
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">
</head>

web.starterHtml:
FrontendAtlas

Interview-style frontend practice: coding tasks, explanations, and reviewable solutions.

solutionBlock.overview: This is a realistic production check: you can have “valid HTML” that still fails basic SEO/mobile standards. The fix is to complete the <head> with the small set of tags almost every team expects in reviews: charset, viewport, meaningful title, and meta description—while keeping styling in the external CSS file.

approaches.title: Approach 1 – Minimal production <head>
approaches.prose: Add UTF-8 encoding first, then the viewport meta for mobile. Write a title that includes the product name plus clear intent (what the page is about). Add a short, human-readable description (one sentence) describing the value. Keep CSS loaded via the existing external stylesheet link and avoid <style>/<script> for this task.
approaches.codeHtml:
FrontendAtlas

Interview-style frontend practice: coding tasks, explanations, and reviewable solutions.

pitfalls: Putting <title> in <body> instead of <head> (invalid placement).
Skipping the viewport meta, causing mobile pages to render zoomed-out.
Using a generic title like “Home” instead of “Brand – page intent”.
Writing a meta description that is empty, too vague, or stuffed with keywords.
techniques: Order in <head> is typically: charset early, then viewport, then title/description, then CSS link.
Meta description should be a readable summary (roughly 1 sentence).

title: Modal: Native <dialog> Confirm (Accessible Naming)

description.summary: Build a native confirm dialog for deleting a project using the HTML <dialog> element. The dialog must be accessible (proper name + description) and must be visible in the preview without JavaScript. Only edit HTML. Do not change CSS.

arguments.name: <dialog open>
arguments.desc: Renders the dialog visible without JS (real apps typically open it via showModal()).

arguments.name: aria-labelledby
arguments.desc: Points to the dialog title element id to provide the dialog’s accessible name.

arguments.name: aria-describedby
arguments.desc: Points to description text id to provide context for screen readers.

arguments.name: <form method="dialog">
arguments.desc: Lets buttons close the dialog and return a value to the opener.

arguments.name: <button value="cancel|confirm">
arguments.desc: Returns the chosen action value when the dialog closes.

returns.desc: A visible, accessible confirm dialog with correct ARIA naming and a native dialog form with Cancel/Delete actions.

examples:
Delete project?

This action cannot be undone.

web.starterHtml:
Project Settings

Danger zone

solutionBlock.overview: Native <dialog> is a real, semantic HTML element for dialogs. Interviewers typically look for: visible title/description, correct accessible naming (aria-labelledby/aria-describedby), and predictable actions using <form method="dialog">. Since this challenge is HTML-only, the dialog is kept visible using the `open` attribute (instead of JS showModal()).

approaches.title: Approach 1 – Visible <dialog> with ARIA naming + dialog form
approaches.prose: Add `open` so the dialog renders in the preview without JavaScript. Put a real title and description inside, then reference them via aria-labelledby/aria-describedby. Use <form method="dialog"> and two buttons with values so the dialog can close and return the selected action in real usage.
approaches.codeHtml:

Danger zone

This action cannot be undone. All project data will be removed.

pitfalls: Forgetting `open` in an HTML-only environment (the dialog exists but is not shown).
Using aria-labelledby/aria-describedby ids that don’t exist.
Not using method="dialog" and losing the native close/return-value behavior.
techniques: Prefer visible text as the source of truth (aria-labelledby points to the visible heading).
Keep action values stable (cancel/confirm) so app code can handle the result reliably.
